description: From Middle English vessel, vessell, from Old French vaissel (compare modern French vaisseau), from Latin vāscellum, diminutive of vāsculum, diminutive of vās (“vase, vessel”).

entries.meaning: (nautical) Any craft designed for transportation on water, such as a ship or boat. [From c.1300]
examples: Hyponyms: ship, boat, barge, raft, canoe, kayak

entries.meaning: A craft designed for transportation through air or space. [From 1915]
(uncountable, obsolete or dialectal) Dishes and cutlery collectively, especially if made of precious metals. [c.1300–c.1600]
examples: All his Vessell was of golde and siluer, pottis, basons, ewers, dysshes, flagons, barels, cuppes, and all other thyngis.

entries.meaning: A container of liquid or other substance, such as a glass, goblet, cup, bottle, bowl, or pitcher. [From c.1300]
A person as a container of qualities or feelings. [From 1382]
examples: A teacher should be a vessel of knowledge.

entries.meaning: (biology) A tube or canal that carries fluid in an animal or plant. [From 1398]
examples: Blood and lymph vessels are found in humans; xylem and phloem vessels are found in plants.

verbs.description: vessel (third-person singular simple present vessels, present participle vesselling or (US) vesseling, simple past and past participle vesselled or (US) vesseled)

examples: Our hony alſo is taken and reputed to be the beſt bycauſe it is harder, better wrought & clenlyer veſſelled vp, thẽ that which cõmeth from beyond the ſea, where they ſtampe and ſtraine their combes, Bées, & young Blow|inges altogither into the ſtuffe, as I haue béene informed.
